item.title: Apple Expands ChatGPT Deal and Mimics Google in AI Comeback Attempt
item.description: The company unveiled a number of AI features at WWDC, though they weren’t the focus of event
item.dc:creator: Chris Welch

media:content.media:description: Tim Cook, chief executive officer of Apple Inc., left, and Craig Federighi, senior vice president of software engineering at Apple Inc., during the Apple Worldwide Developers Conference (WWDC) at Apple Park campus in Cupertino, California, US, on Monday, June 9, 2025. Apple Inc. unveiled a new operating system interface called Liquid Glass at its annual Worldwide Developers Conference, calling it the company’s broadest design update ever.

item.title: Amazon Whole Foods Distributor Breach Disrupts Deliveries
item.description: A cybersecurity breach at United Natural Foods Inc., the primary distributor for Amazon.com Inc.’s Whole Foods grocery markets, has disrupted deliveries and forced the company’s systems offline.
item.dc:creator: Margi Murphy

media:content.media:description: United Natural Foods Inc

item.title: Trump Says He Wishes Musk ‘Very Well’
item.description: President Donald Trump tells reporters that he would retain Starlink internet service at the White House and wished Elon Musk “very well.”

item.title: Apple’s macOS Tahoe to Be Final Operating System to Work on Intel Macs
item.description: Apple Inc.’s new macOS Tahoe 26 will be the final Mac operating system software that will work on Macs running Intel Corp. processors, the company said Monday following its developer conference.
item.dc:creator: Samantha Kelly, Mark Gurman

media:content.media:description: macOS Tahoe 26

item.title: Roblox Taps Paramount’s Naveen Chopra as New CFO
item.description: Roblox Corp. tapped Paramount Global’s Naveen Chopra as its new chief financial officer, effective June 30.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia D'Anastasio

media:content.media:description: Naveen Chopra Photographer: Brian Feinzimer/Variety/Getty Images

item.title: Fuji Media Keeps Real Estate Spinoff in Play as Activists Circle
item.description: Fuji Media Holdings Inc.’s incoming president said “all options” regarding its real estate operations remain on the table, including a possible spinoff along the lines of activist investor demands.
item.dc:creator: Yuki Furukawa

media:content.media:description: Kenji Shimizu Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

item.title: Cracking the Code of Making Old Clothes New Again
item.description: Discarded clothing is an environmental scourge. But across Europe, companies are joining forces to build new technologies that could make recycling scalable.
item.dc:creator: Paul Tullis

media:content.media:description: Discarded clothing has become a global environmental problem, but in Europe and elsewhere, new methods of recycling may present a solution. Above, post-consumer textile bales ready for recycling at Brightfiber in Amsterdam.

item.title: Investors Look To Apple's WWDC For Guidance | Bloomberg Tech 6/9/2025
item.description: Bloomberg’s Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow discuss Apple's software and AI goals as the company kicks off its annual Developers Conference in Cupertino. Plus, AI and tariffs top the agenda for China-US trade talks as discussions get underway in London. And, Warner Brothers Discovery splits its streaming and cable businesses. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Mexico’s Coppel to Invest $4.2 Billion in E-Commerce, New Stores
item.description: Grupo Coppel SA, Mexico’s largest private retailer, will spend 80 billion pesos ($4.2 billion) over five years on investments including a new e-commerce platform to double the portion of digital transactions to 20% of total sales.
item.dc:creator: Jose Orozco, Valentine Hilaire

media:content.media:description: A Grupo Coppel retail store in Mexico City.

item.title: Apple’s AI Takes Back Seat to Design, iPad Revamp at WWDC Event
item.description: Apple Inc. unveiled the most sweeping software redesign in its history, aiming to make the company’s device lineup more cohesive and useful, even while doing little to upgrade its struggling artificial intelligence platform.
item.dc:creator: Mark Gurman

media:content.media:description: Apple unveiled a new lineup of operating systems named for the coming year.

item.title: How to Install Apple’s Redesigned Operating Systems — If You’re a Developer
item.description: Apple Inc. on Monday released the first developer beta previews for its upcoming iOS 26, iPadOS 26, macOS Tahoe 26, tvOS 26, watchOS 26, and visionOS 26 updates. The software is intended to give app makers an opportunity to explore the visual redesign and new features ahead of a wide rollout in the fall. A public beta will be available in July for those who want to test the major software upgrades several months in advance.
item.dc:creator: Chris Welch

media:content.media:description: Installing the developer beta only requires a few steps.

item.title: Warner Bros. to Split Into Streaming, Cable TV Companies
item.description: Warner Bros. Discovery Inc. is splitting itself in half, unshackling its fast-growing streaming business from the struggling legacy media channels and setting up two independent companies that could pursue deals on their own.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Miller, Amy Thomson

media:content.media:description: Warner Bros. Discovery’s 2025 Upfront Presentation at The Theater at Madison Square Garden in New York City, on May 14.

item.title: Trump Says China ‘Not Easy’ as Trade Talks to Continue Tuesday
item.description: Trade talks between the US and China will continue into a second day, according to a US official, as the two sides look to ease tensions over shipments of technology and rare earth elements.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Tyler Kendall

item.title: Apple Unveils Liquid Glass Operating System at WWDC
item.description: Apple Inc. unveiled a new operating system interface called Liquid Glass at its annual Worldwide Developers Conference, an event that focused heavily on aesthetics and design elements rather than software breakthroughs. Bloomberg's Ed Ludlow was there and reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Key Takeaways From Apple’s 2025 Developer’s Conference
item.description: Apple Inc.’s 2025 Worldwide Developers Conference was jam-packed. Here are the highlights:
item.dc:creator: Mark Gurman

media:content.media:description: Tim Cook, chief executive officer of Apple Inc., during the Apple Worldwide Developers Conference (WWDC) at Apple Park campus in Cupertino, California, US, on Monday, June 9, 2025. Apple Inc. unveiled a new operating system interface called Liquid Glass at its annual Worldwide Developers Conference, calling it the company’s broadest design update ever.

item.title: Swedish ‘Vibe Coding’ Startup Lovable in Talks for $1.5 Billion Valuation
item.description: Lovable, an AI startup that streamlines software development, is in talks for a large funding round that would make it one of Europe’s biggest artificial intelligence newcomers.
item.dc:creator: Kate Clark, Mark Bergen

item.title: Apple Shares Fall While AI-Focused Event Is Underway

media:content.media:description: Apple presents the new Liquid Glass design at WWDC in Cupertino on June 9.

item.title: Financier Lex Greensill Decries ‘Code of Silence’ Around SoftBank Deals
item.description: Financier Lex Greensill said there was a “code of silence” around a series of transactions with SoftBank Group Corp. to keep potential losses hidden, in his first public court appearance since the high-profile collapse of his firm.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Browning

media:content.media:description: Lex Greensill, center, in London on June 9.

item.title: Apple Event to Put Focus on ‘Existential Risk’ of AI Struggles
item.description: Apple Inc. shares have been heavily tethered to US trade policies this year, but its annual developer’s conference could refocus Wall Street’s attention on a potentially bigger problem: its struggles with artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Vlastelica

item.title: Tesla Hit With a Pair of Downgrades Amid Fallout From Trump Feud
item.description: Tesla Inc. was hit with a pair of downgrades on Monday, underscoring mounting concerns on Wall Street about the electric-vehicle maker’s outlook following last week’s clash between Chief Executive Elon Musk and President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Vlastelica

item.title: IonQ Buys UK Quantum Computing Startup in $1 Billion Deal
item.description: US quantum computing company IonQ has agreed to buy UK startup Oxford Ionics in a $1.08 billion deal that highlights increasing commercial confidence in what has largely been an experimental field of computing.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Solon

media:content.media:description: Oxford Ionics

item.title: Grab Plays Down GoTo Deal, Says No Talks ‘at This Time’
item.description: Grab Holdings Ltd. said it isn’t in talks to acquire GoTo Group “at this time,” signaling it’s halting or at least pausing a planned $7 billion acquisition of its Southeast Asia internet peer.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Poh

media:content.media:description: Grab delivery drivers in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Aug. 13, 2024. Grab Holdings Ltd. is scheduled to release earnings results on Aug. 15.

item.title: Trump-Musk Meltdown Spurs Flash of Long-Gone Twitter on X
item.description: Welcome to Tech In Depth, our daily newsletter with reporting and analysis about the business of tech from Bloomberg’s journalists around the world. Today, Austin Carr writes that President Donald Trump’s public feud with Elon Musk last week provided a brief reminder of the way Twitter used to be a hub for shared cultural moments.
item.dc:creator: Austin Carr

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, right, presents a gift to Elon Musk, chief executive officer of Tesla Inc., during a news conference in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. The event gives an opportunity for the president and his largest campaign benefactor to dispel any notion of an acrimonious divorce.

item.title: Tailscale Founder Talks Future IPO as Revenue Surges on AI Adoption
item.description: Canadian software networking startup Tailscale Inc. is sketching out a long-range plan to go public after unexpectedly becoming a beneficiary of the artificial intelligence boom and quickly doubling its valuation to $1.5 billion.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Seal

media:content.media:description: Avery Pennarun

item.title: BP Puts AI at the Heart of Its Efforts to Boost Performance
item.description: When engineers prepare to drill for oil, they know the spot deep underground where the well must end and can choose their starting point, but there are many possible routes in between.
item.dc:creator: Mitchell Ferman

media:content.media:description: BP's Center for High-Performance Computing.

item.title: Trump’s Golden Dome Creates Opening for Space Force to Gain Relevance
item.description: Five years after its formation during President Donald Trump’s first administration prompted jokes about the Star Trek-style logo and inspired a Netflix Inc. sitcom with Steve Carell, the US Space Force is still looking for respect.
item.dc:creator: Bruce Einhorn, Sana Pashankar

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump at a White House ceremony displaying the Space Force’s new flag in 2020.

item.title: AI Infrastructure Trade Roars Back as Tech Giants Boost Spending
item.description: Shares of companies that provide infrastructure for artificial-intelligence development are soaring after a tumble earlier this year, as spending from Big Tech restores investor confidence in the volatile sector.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Kniazhevich

item.title: UK’s AI Talent Is Envy of World and Needs Support, Nvidia CEO Says
item.description: Nvidia Corp. Chief Executive Officer Jensen Huang described the UK’s artificial intelligence talent as the “envy of the world,” specifically calling out its researchers, universities and startups. But he said the country needs to more infrastructure to unlock their potential.
item.dc:creator: Amy Thomson

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer and Jensen Huang during London Tech Week on June 9. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: Taiwan Exports to US Hit Record as Two Sides Talk Trade
item.description: Taiwan’s exports to the US jumped to a record, surging as companies fired off shipments before any tariffs hit — gains that come as the two sides try to hammer out a trade deal.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee, Betty Hou

media:content.media:description: An image of a semiconductor wafer. Photographer: I-Hwa Cheng/Bloomberg
